title: Instagram Rebrand Script
content:
Instagram's old logo

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150428171556im_/http:/typophile.com/files/InstagramLogoOldVer_3581.jpg)
 looks like Billabong 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150428171556im_/http:/typophile.com/files/BillabongAsInstagram_5958.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/typeassociates/billabong/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150428171556/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typeassociates/billabong/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/typeassociates/billabong/") and the lettering of the reworked logo 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150428171556im_/http:/typophile.com/files/InstagramLogoRemakeByMackeySaturdayA_4444.jpg)
 which was created by Mackey Saturday, is apparently a smoothed out revision rather than a different font. [http://taufanwords.wordpress.com/2013/08/31/the-fonts/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150428171556/http:/taufanwords.wordpress.com/2013/08/31/the-fonts/ "http://taufanwords.wordpress.com/2013/08/31/the-fonts/")  
I would be interested in opinions as to which digital font is closest to the new logo.  
Thanks.  
Don

My 2 cent... I'm not great fan of this rework. It gives the impression of exactly what it is, a rework. /m and /n look out of the scope now, still too close of Billabong's, /n and /s feel unbalanced together (don't like the way /s x-height has been reduced to be aligned with the rest), /g loop and following /r look weird creating a big gap probably because the designer wanted to keep the tracking (making /g leg longer and reworking loop).  
That said you may like to have a look to `[Bad link]` and `[Bad link]` fonts, 2 fresh and new foundries.

Artimasa’s Authentica, though, is a shame, more so with a name like that… (see [http://www.losttype.com/font/?name=wisdom\_script](http://web.archive.org/web/20150428171556/http:/www.losttype.com/font/?name=wisdom_script "http://www.losttype.com/font/?name=wisdom\_script")).  
It makes one wonder about the legitimacy of the other designs too.

Edited:  
Many thanks to both of you for the font suggestions. Quite helpful.  
Ryuk, your critique is perceptive Gives me a better insight into the merits, or perhaps demerits, of the redesign. I agree a cursive style \_s\_ works better when it is allowed to punch above the X-height. The cursive letter \_r\_ is always a problem. Handling the \_gr\_ link is particularly difficult. Should the tail of \_g\_ snake up to follow the pattern of letters like \_a\_ and \_e\_, compare to Aaron Script by Seniors

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150428171556im_/http:/typophile.com/files/AaronScriptAsInstagramSM_4703.jpg)
 or should it stay below the baseline and allow a break in the cursive structure. I wonder if that would have been a better version for \_Instagram\_? compare to Shintia Script by Seniors  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150428171556im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ShintiaScriptAsInstagramSM_6139.jpg)
  
Riccardo, indeed Authentica is close to clonesville -- "legitimacy" in the font business is often an oxymoron that matches "jumbo shrimp." :)  
Just for ease of future reference:  
 [https://creativemarket.com/Seniors](http://web.archive.org/web/20150428171556/https:/creativemarket.com/Seniors "https://creativemarket.com/Seniors")  
 [https://creativemarket.com/artimasa](http://web.archive.org/web/20150428171556/https:/creativemarket.com/artimasa "https://creativemarket.com/artimasa")  
Don

About the Instagram reworking, I understand the need to smooth the logo down and to make it more a logo and less a word set in a nice font. But I think the result took away too much of the liveliness from the original. In this regard, for the g\_r pair probably a more “twisted” curve would have helped (less tame loop for |g|, less wide counter for |r|, a bit like your Fertigo Script sample\*).  
As for Authentica, it’s not the first time someone is called out for ripping off Wisdom Script (see [http://typophile.com/node/93171](http://web.archive.org/web/20150428171556/http:/typophile.com/node/93171 "http://typophile.com/node/93171")).  
If you need to “improve” upon an existing script, at least do it with something which allows it (example: [https://www.behance.net/gallery/Blenda-Script-Free-Font/13832171](http://web.archive.org/web/20150428171556/https:/www.behance.net/gallery/Blenda-Script-Free-Font/13832171 "https://www.behance.net/gallery/Blenda-Script-Free-Font/13832171")).

\* Although in Fertigo |g|’s loop could look a bit cramped, and the joining a bit thin.

Good point: liveliness vs. regularity in script font design. This seems to me to be perhaps the most difficult issue for a script font maker. The new \_Instagram\_ logo does indeed seem to emphasize regularity at the expense of liveliness.  
Blenda Script as a remake of Lobster -- one of the most successful font designs of recent years -- is not close to \_Instagram\_ because it is too crisp and regular for a match. Is it an improvement? Perhaps. In any case, It looks like a good font for some uses.  
Thanks for the comment on the \_gr\_ pair issue.  
Don

Sorry to somewhat hijacking the thread, my links were intended to illustrated points only tangential to the main topic.  
On the question on which digital font is close to the revised Instagram logo, I’d say that the closer general style is the modulated-but-not-too-contrasted upright brushy cursive favoured by vintage advertising, sign painters and phototype.
